questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought with a history of chronic cough, and foul-smelling stools. His sibling who had similar complaints died a few years back. Sweat chloride test and CFTR gene studies were done. CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chloride Chloride ion is the ion affected in CFTR mutation . The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In this condition, CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of Cl- ions.

Highyeild:

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive inherited disease of the mucus and sweat glands There is a defect in ion transport of epithelial cells that affects fluid secretion in Exocrine glands (pancreas) Epithelial lining of respiratory, gastrointestinal and reproductive tract. Pathophysiology The primary defect in cystic fibrosis results from abnormal function of an epithelial chloride channel protein encoded by the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q 31.2 . Protein encoded by CFTR is a chloride channel through which chloride passes. The most common mutation is delta F508 In cystic fibrosis activity of the chloride channel is decreased . ENaC is inhibited by normally functioning CFTR; hence, in cystic fibrosis, ENaC activity increases , markedly augmenting sodium uptake across the apical membrane (especially in respiratory and gastrointestinal systems). Diagnosis : Based on evidence of CFTR Dysfunction Elevated sweat chloride 2 than 60 mEq/L on two occasions Two disease-causing CFTR mutations Abnormal nasal potential difference

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option A. Extracellular volume contraction causes secondary hyperaldosteronism, which leads to hypokalemia from potassium wasting in both sweat and urine. Option B. People with cystic fibrosis are at an increased risk of sodium loss , and therefore hyponatremia, during times of increased sweating or diarrhea Option D. Hydrogen ion - following ion imbalance occur in mutation of CFTR GENE NOTE: In infants with Cystic fibrosis , Hyponatremic, hypochloremic dehydration with metabolic alkalosis has been reported.

questions.text: A young infant of 2 months came to the emergency with watery diarrhea and altered sensorium. Which of the following differentials is suitable based on the findings: Severe dehydration Hemolytic uremic syndrome Hypokalemia Cerebral vein thrombosis Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, c, d The differential diagnosis in a child with a history of watery diarrhea and altered sensorium include severe dehydration, cerebral thrombosis and hyponatremia.

Highyeild:

Causes Of Altered Sensorium/Seizures With Diarrhea Hypo/Hypernatremia Hypoglycemia Encephalitis/Meningitis Febrile Seizures Cerebral Or Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is thrombotic microangiopathy characterized by a triad of symptoms Thrombocytopenia Acute renal impairment Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia Hemolytic uremic syndrome is most often associated with a gastrointestinal illness Presents with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Diarrhea is often bloody and is secondary to colitis from the invasion of the gastrointestinal cells or ischemia related to a vascular lesion

questions.text: The causative agent of this condition is associated with which of the following disorders?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erythema infectiosum The given image shows classical slapped cheek appearance, which is suggestive of Erythema infectiosum / 5th disease

Highyeild:

Erythema infectiosum aka “fifth disease” as it is 1 of the 6 most common viral rash illnesses found in children. This febrile illness typically affects children 5 to 15 years old . Cause : Human parvovirus B 19 Route of transmission : Primarily via droplets from respiratory secretions and can spread via blood exposure After initial viremia, the classic erythematous malar rash involving the cheek s with surrounding oral pallor develops ( slapped-cheek rash ). This facial rash can last 4 to 5 days. The course of infection can also present with arthralgias. More common in adults than children. Women are more affected by joint symptoms than men. The affected joints are usually symmetric.

Extraedge:

Viral Infection Rash Chaterictics Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever Centripetal Pleomorphic Dewdrops on rose Appearance Rubella On Day 1 over the face Measles 4th Day over the face and retroauricular Origin Erythema Infectiosum Slapped cheek appearance Exanthem Subitum Maculopapular rash Infectious Mononucleosis Maculopapular rash

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is live vaccination not contraindicated? Wiskott Aldrich syndrome DiGeorge syndrome Ataxia telangiectasia Complement deficiency Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

d only Live vaccine is not contraindicated in complement deficiency. In Wiskott Aldrich syndrome, Digeorge syndrome, Ataxia Telangiectasia live vaccine are contraindicated

Highyeild:

In Wiskott Aldrich syndrome, Digeorge syndrome, Ataxia telangiectasia, T cell immunity is impaired . There is a risk of severe or fatal infections due to live vaccines. Whereas, in Complement deficiency, T cell and B cell immunity is intact and this is crucial for building an immune response against live vaccines.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Wiskott Aldrich syndrome : Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome(WAS) is an X- linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder, caused by mutations in the Wiskott- Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes. In patients with partial T cell deficiencies (e.g., partial DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome), all live viral vaccines are avoided. DiGeorge syndrome Is due to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Cell-mediated immunity is defective due to decreased T-cells. Affected individuals also have depressed graft rejection, hypocalcemia, and cardiac defects. For severe T cell deficiencies (e.g.severe combined immunodeficiency disease [SCID], complete DiGeorge syndrome), no live viral or live bacterial vaccines should be given. Ataxia telangiectasia is caused due to mutation of the ATM gene. This gene is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair leads to impaired lg isotype switching and the formation of antigen receptors. As a result,the patient is immunodeficient with partial T Cell deficiency, and hence live vaccines are avoided.

questions.text: According to NADAS criteria, which of the following comes minor criteria? Abnormal second heart sound Abnormal BP Diastolic murmur Systolic grade 3 murmur Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2 Nada’s minor criteria includes abnormal second heart sound and abnormal bp.

Highyeild:

Nada’s criteria is used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children.the presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease. Nada’s criteria for congenital heart disease. Major criteria Minor criteria Systolic murmur grade 3 or more Systolic murmur grade

questions.text: Baby born with Meconium stained liquor, which of following are recommended as per Neonatal Resuscitation Guidelines: Intrapartum -Tracheal suctioning in case of non vigorous baby Gentle suction of mouth and nose in vigorous baby Intrapartum suctioning of nose and nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder PPV in case of non vigorous baby after early steps Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B & D only

Highyeild:

Routine intrapartum oropharyngeal and nasopharyngeal suctioning for infants born with clear and meconium-stained amniotic fluid is not recommended. ventilation within the first minute of life in non- breathing or ineffectively breathing infants and this should not be delayed, especially in the bradycardic infant. Nice guideline for Meconium stained liquor management

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, and erythematous desquamation of the skin as shown in the images below. A 2D echo shows a coronary aneurysm. What is the first line of treatment for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IVIG The clinical presentation described,including fever for 6 days,strawberry tongue,conjunctival congestion and peeling of the skin is suggestive of a condition called kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness that primarily affects young children.

Highyeild:

Kawasaki disease is an acute, febrile, usually s elf-limited illness of infancy and childhood associated with an arteritis of mainly large- to medium-sized vessels. Approximately 80% of patients are younger than 4 years of age. Symptoms Persistent high fever is a hallmark symptom, typically lasting for at least five days. Mucocutaneous Changes: Changes in the mucous membranes and skin, such as redness, swelling, and peeling of the hands and feet, cracked lips, and a " strawberry tongue. " Conjunctival Injection : Redness and inflammation of the conjunctiva, the white part of the eyes. Enlargement of lymph nodes , particularly in the neck. A characteristic desquamative rash may appear on the trunk and genital area. Cardiovascular Complications : Kawasaki disease can lead to inflammation of the coronary arteries, which can result in the development of coronary artery aneurysms or other cardiovascular issues. Timely treatment with intravenou s immunoglobulin (IVIG) significantly reduces the risk of coronary artery complications. NOTE : Both Kawasaki disease and scarlet fever can present with fever and skin-related symptoms, it's important to differentiate between the two based on the specific clinical features, age group, and underlying causes. Lymph node enlargement in Kawasaki while Only tonsil enlargement in scarlet fever. Please make this a paragraph with the first line bolded and next 5 lines as bulleted points Diagnosis requires unexplained fever for > 5 days in addition to the presence of > 4 of the following: Oral mucosa changes, including red or cracked lips, pharyngeal erythema, or strawberry tongue Bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, sparing the limbus Cervical lymphadenopathy, usually unilateral, with one node > 1.5 cm in size Polymorphous rash Extremity changes (erythema of palms and soles, swelling of hands and feet, periungual desquamation in the convalescent phase)

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B: Aspirin has anti inflammatory, anti platelet properties which make it useful in Kawasaki disease, but is not the first line agent Option C: LMWH- It is not a recommended treatment for kawasaki disease. Heparin is occasionally used in certain cases of kawasaki disease. Option D: Warfarin is not used in the treatment of kawasaki disease,as it is an anticoagulant and does not address the underlying inflammatory process the underlying inflammatory process of the disease.

questions.text: The causative agent of this condition is associated with which of the following conditions? (SUBJECT:Pediatrics)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pure red cell aplasia Erythema infectiosum, or slapped cheek syndrome is one of several possible manifestations of infection by parvovirus B19

Highyeild:

Fifth disease is a childhood condition that appears as a bright red rash on your child's cheeks. It's nicknamed “ slapped cheek disease ” because of this rash. A virus called parvovirus B19 causes the fifth disease . Pure red cell aplasia or erythroblastopenia refers to a type of anemia affecting the precursors to red blood cells. In PRCA, the bone marrow ceases to produce red blood cells. Signs and symptoms may include: Pale appearance Rapid heart rate Fatigue Causes of PRCA include: Autoimmune disease. Thymoma . Viral infections such as HIV, herpes, parvovirus B19 (Fifth disease), or hepatitis Association of pure red cell aplasia with T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia is well recognized, especially in China Many cases of PRCA are considered idiopathic in that there is no discernible cause detected Drugs such as mycophenolic acid or erythropoietin. The term "hereditary pure red cell aplasia has been used to refer to Diamond–Blackfan anemia

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option B. Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection of the skin that results in small raised pink lesions with a dimple in the center. Option C. Thymoma and thymic carcinoma, also called thymic epithelial tumors (TETs), are two types of rare cancers that can form in the cells that cover the outside surface of the thymus Option D. Lymphoma is a group of blood and lymph tumors that develop from lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). The name typically refers to just the cancerous versions rather than all such tumours. Signs and symptoms may include enlarged lymph nodes, fever, drenching sweats, unintended weight loss.
